columns.text: In this problem, we will determine how much monthly withdrawals we can make for 25 years from our savings account if we plan to save for retirement for 30 years by investing in a bond and a stock accounts.

To calculate the monthly withdrawals we can make for 25 years, we will combine the earnings from both investments. We will compute the future value of the stock account and the bond account for 30 years.

To determine the future value of each investment, we will use the future value of an annuity formula. The future value annuity refers to the value of the investment at a future date considering the rate of return and the compounding of periods. The future value of an annuity can be calculated using the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Future Value of an Annuity} &=C\times\dfrac{\left(1+r\right)^t-1}{r}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$C$, which represent the constant payment or the cash amount\
$r$, which refers to the rate\
$t$, which symbolizes the period

First, let's calculate the future value of the investment on the stock account.

The stock account requires a $750 monthly investment with an expected return of 10%. Hence we will consider the following details in calculating the future value of the stock investment:

| Particulars      |        |
|------------------|--------|
| Rate of return   | 10%    |
| Constant payment |  $750  |
| Period |  30 years  |

Since the rate is compounded monthly, to calculate the investment's future value, we will multiply the years by the number of months a year.

$$ \begin{aligned}
t &= 30\times12
\\[5pt]
&= 360
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the period we will use in our calculation is 360.

Next, calculate the bond's future value.

The bond investment monthly requires $250 with a 6% rate of return for 30 years. Therefore we will consider the following details in solving the value of the bond in the future:

| Particulars      |        |
|------------------|--------|
| Rate of return   | 6%    |
| Constant payment |  $250  |
| Period |  30 years  |

Let's compute the period to be used in calculating the bond's future value. Since the rate is compounded monthly, multiply the year by the number of months a year.

$$ \begin{aligned}
t &= 30\times12
\\[5pt]
&= 360
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the period we will use in our calculation is 360.

Let's no calculate the total earning after 30 years from two investments
$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Total earnings} &= \$1,695,365.94+\$251,128.76
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\$1,946,494.70 }
\end{aligned}$$

As can be seen in our calculation, the combined future value of our investment is $1,946,494.70.

Finally, after calculating the combined future value of our investment, we will now determine the monthly payment we can receive for 25 years. Since the combined investment is put into one account with a rate of return of 5%, it's also the rate we will consider in calculating the monthly withdrawals.

Since the computation of the monthly withdrawal is after 30 years after retirement, the combined future value of the investment will be the present value. Hence, we will consider the following details in determining the monthly withdrawals:

| Particulars      |        |
|------------------|--------|
| Rate   | 5%    |
| Present value |  $1,946,494.70  |
| Period |  25 years  |

We will use the spreadsheet function PMT to calculate the monthly withdrawals for 25 years. The PMT is a financial function that calculates the payment based on the period and the rate of return. The PMT function can be used utilizing the following formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
PMT&=(\text{rate},nper,pv,[fv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

$nper$, which refers to the period\
$pv$, which represent the present value\
$fv$, the future value\
$type$, which indicates the basis of the calculation, either year-end or beginning of the year

The calculation requires the value of the monthly payment received for 25 years. Hence, we will convert the rate into a monthly value.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Rate} &=\dfrac{0.05}{12}
\\[10pt]
&= 0.004167
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, we will use the rate of 0.4167%.

Next, also convert the period to months.


$$ \begin{aligned}
t &= 25\times32
\\[5pt]
&= 300
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the period we will use in our calculation is 300.

Let's now calculate the monthly withdrawals on the spreadsheet. Note that the present value should be negative for the function to work correctly.

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/dc729aea-6e23-494d-8582-3ffda4d25370-1642084308990253.png)
 

**Based on our calculations, after 30 years, the monthly withdrawable amount for 25 years in our retirement account is $11,379.47.**

To conclude, we determined the monthly receivable amount for retirement by first calculating and combining the future value of the two investments and using the rate of return of 5% divided by 12 to determine the withdrawable amount monthly for 25 years.
